talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Media, upon notice:

quote.para: How many co-production films has Film Australia participated in during the last 12 months and how many are planned for the future.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: In the last twelve months Film Australia has participated in two co-productions with the National Film Board of Canada and one with B.B.C. television.

Discussions are shortly to take place with the New Zealand National Film Unit with the object of setting up at least one co-production in the future, and in addition the possibility of local co-production with the Australian Broadcasting Commission is being explored.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Media, upon notice:

quote.para: What investigations, if any, is the Department of the Media making into the latest overseas developments in sound and projection.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: The main investigations in this field are being made by Film Australia, which operates within the Broadcasting and Film Division of my Department.

Apart from regular perusal of trade publications, follow-up correspondence with contacts established overseas and continuous liaison with local representatives of overseas manufacturers of sound and projection equipment and with others in the industry. Film Australia sends representatives overseas at regular intervals to study developments in the industry. The last such visit took place in June- August 1973, when a member of Film Australia's sound department visited all the main overseas manufacturers of sound and projection equipment with the express purpose of bringing
Film Australia's knowledge of professional studio equipment in this field up-to-date before finalisation of plans to equip new facilities currently under construction.

answer.para: Two- Way Radios on Small Craft

talk.start.para: - On 19 March 1974, Senator Rae asked me, as the Minister representing the Postmaster-General, the following question without notice:

quote.para: On 12 December last year I asked a question in the following terms:

item.para: 1 ) Is the Minister aware that the regulations in relation to the use of 2-way radios on small craft will require that as from the end of this year only single side band radios may be installed; (2)I also asked whether it was correct that at the moment there is a shortage of these radios;
Whether it was correct that the cost of them was four times as great as the cost of double side band radios;

Whether the Minister was aware that the almost inevitable consequence of the enforcement of the present proposition would be a reduction in the possible safety provided by the use of those radios; (5)I asked for a reconsideration of the decision.

quote.para: The Minister said that he would take it up with the PostmasterGeneral. I now ask whether there have been any results?

question.para: The Postmaster-General has now furnished me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) Yes- the decision to require radio installations in small vessels to convert to single side band operation was taken by the Government in 1970. This was based on recommendations by the Panel of Experts set up by the International Telecommunications Union following the 1959 Administrative Radio Conference and the Huxley Frequency Allocation Review Committee, convened by the Australian Government in 1960, as a means of relieving the serious congestion in the High Frequency Spectrum.

It is true that there is a world wide shortage of some components for radio transceivers and manufacturers are experiencing supply difficulties. I understand, however, that three manufacturers which have equipment approved under Australian Marine Specifications are in a position to fill orders and several others will be in this position shortly.

The present cost of Single Side Band apparatus is greater than Double Side Band. This cost is subject to considerable variation however, depending on the complexity of design and the user requirements. Generally, for sets of equivalent standard the cost of single side band apparatus would be twice that of double side band. It could be anticipated however, that the cost difference will narrow as production of the latter is increased to meet the abovementioned requirements.

No- the single side band provisions should not result in a reduction in safety standards as in any case double side band equipment may continue to be employed on the international distress and calling frequency of 2 1 82 kilohertz for the exchange of distress, urgency and safety messages.
) It is not proposed to vary the present arrangements.
